facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1953 filed in Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 34 of 1953.

facts.text: Appeal from Judgment and Order dated 5th January 1953 of High Court of Judicature at Allahabad Lucknow Bench

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated the 5th January, 1953, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Lucknow Bench , Lucknow  Kidwai and Bhargava JJ.

facts.text: High Court appeal from Sessions Judge Sitapur judgment dated 19th January 1952 in Sessions Case No. 97 of 1951

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeal Register No. 24 of 1952 and Capital Sentence Register No. 4 of 1952 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 19th January 1952, of the Court of the Sessions Judge, Sitapur, in Sessions Case No. 97 of 1951.

facts.text: Three appellants prosecuted for murder of Babu Singh

anchor.surface_text: We have three appellants before us. All were prosecuted for the murder of one Babu Singh.

facts.text: Surendra Singh convicted of murder and sentenced to death by Sessions Court

anchor.surface_text: Of these, Surendra Singh alone was convicted of the murder and was sentenced to death.

facts.text: Other two appellants convicted under section 302 Indian Penal Code and sentenced to three years RI and fine Rs 200

anchor.surface_text: The other two were convicted under section 302, Indian Penal Code. Each was sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment and to a fine of Rs. 200.

facts.text: All three appealed to High Court Allahabad Lucknow Bench heard on 5th December 1952 by Kidwai and Bhargava JJ

anchor.surface_text: All three appealed to the High Court at Allahabad  Lucknow Bench  and the appeal was heard on Fifth December, 1952, by Kidwai and Bhargava JJ. Judgment was reserved.

facts.text: Bhargava J transferred to Allahabad before judgment delivered

anchor.surface_text: Before it could be delivered Bhargava J. was transferred to Allahabad.

facts.text: Bhargava J dictated judgment purporting to be joint judgment, signed every page but did not date it, sent to Kidwai J at Lucknow

anchor.surface_text: While there he dictated a, judgment purporting to do so on behalf of himself and his brother Judge, that is to say it purported to be a joint judgment he used the pronoun we and number I. He signed every page of the judgment as well as at the end but did number date it. He then sent this to Kidwai J. at Lucknow.

facts.text: Bhargava J died on 24th December 1952

anchor.surface_text: He died on 24th December, 1952, before the judgment was delivered.

facts.text: Kidwai J purported to deliver the judgment on 5th January 1953, signed and dated it

anchor.surface_text: After his death, on 5th January, 1953, his brother Judge Kidwai J. purported to deliver the judgment of the court. He signed it and dated it. The date he placed on it was 5th January, 1953,

facts.text: High Court dismissed the appeal and confirmed death sentence

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was dismissed and the sentence of death was confirmed.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court Rules framed in 1952 came into force on 15th September 1952

anchor.surface_text: The Allahabad High Court framed its present set of Rules in 1952. They came into force on the 15th of September in that year.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on 16th November 1953 by BOSE J

anchor.surface_text: 1953. November 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.

facts.text: High Court judgment held invalid because Bhargava J died before delivery

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows appeal and sets aside High Court order

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court which purports to be its judgment is set aside.

facts.text: Case remanded to High Court for re-hearing and delivery of proper judgment

anchor.surface_text: As it is no longer possible for the Bench which heard the appeal and the confirmation proceedings to deliver a valid judgment we send the case back to the High Court for re-hearing and delivery of a proper judgment.

facts.text: Order for stay dated 25th May 1953 has no longer effect on 23rd November 1953

anchor.surface_text: 1953. November 23. BOSE J.The order for stay dated the 25th May, 1953, has no longer expended itself.

facts.text: Bhargava J used pronoun 'we' in the judgment draft

anchor.surface_text: that is to say it purported to be a joint judgment he used the pronoun we and number I.

facts.text: Kidwai J placed date 5th January 1953 on judgment with Bhargava J's signature still there

anchor.surface_text: Bhargava J.s signature was still there and anyone reading the judgment and knowing the facts would conclude that Bhargava J. was a party to the delivery on 5th January, 1953.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant: Jai Gopal Sethi, K. P. Gupta

anchor.surface_text: Jai Gopal Sethi  K. P. Gupta, with him  for the appellant.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent: C. Mathur and Onkar Nath Srivastava

anchor.surface_text: C. Mathur and Onkar Nath Srivastava for the respondent.

facts.text: High Court appeal in Criminal Appeal Register No. 24 of 1952 and Capital Sentence Register No. 4 of 1952

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeal Register No. 24 of 1952 and Capital Sentence Register No. 4 of 1952
We have three appellants before us. All were prosecuted for the murder of one Babu Singh.
The other two were convicted under section 225, Indian Penal Code. Each was sentenced to three years rigorous imprisonment and to a fine of Rs. 200.

anchor.surface_text: We are concerned with the following in Chapter VII dealing with the judgment and decree, namely rules 1.4. issues.text: whether this judgment could be validly delivered after the death of one of the two Judges who heard the appeal

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was dismissed and the sentence of death was confirmed. The question is whether this judgment could be validly delivered after the death of one of the two Judges who heard the appeal. The arguments covered a wide range but we intend to confine ourselves to the facts of this case and only deal with the narrower issues which arise here.

issues.text: what is a judgment within the meaning of these sections

anchor.surface_text: the question still remains what is a judgment, for it is the judgment which decides the case and affects the rights and liberties of the parties that is the core of the matter and, as the Privy Council say, the whole purpose of these rules is to secure certainty in the ascertainment of what the judgment was.

issues.text: whether a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things

anchor.surface_text: These rules use the word pronounced in some places and delivered in others. Counsel tried to make capital out of this and said that a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things. We do not intend to construe these rules too technically because they are designed, as indeed are all rules, to further the ends of justice and must not be viewed too narrowly nor do we desire to curtail the jurisdiction which the Privy Council point out is inherent in courts to make good inherent defects caused by accidents such as death.

issues.text: whether the court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect

anchor.surface_text: The court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The case of a Judge who has gone on leave before signing the judgment may call for more comment, but even so the convenience of the court and the interest of litigants must prevail. The defect is merely an irregularity.

issues.text: whether Judges have the right to change their mind up to the moment the judgment is delivered

anchor.surface_text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae, and indeed last minute alterations sometimes do occur. Therefore, however much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court.

arguments.claim: a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things

anchor.surface_text: These rules use the word pronounced in some places and delivered in others. Counsel tried to make capital out of this and said that a judgment had to be both pronounced and delivered and that they were two different things. We do not intend to construe these rules too technically because they are designed, as indeed are all rules, to further the ends of justice and must not be viewed too narrowly nor do we desire to curtail the jurisdiction which the Privy Council point out is inherent in courts to make good inherent defects caused by accidents such as death.

arguments.court_response: Rules designed to further ends of justice, not to be construed technically; inherent jurisdiction to cure defects

arguments.claim: judgment is valid even if not signed due to judge's death or leave; defect is irregularity curable by inherent jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The case of a Judge who has gone on leave before signing the judgment may call for more comment, but even so the convenience of the court and the interest of litigants must prevail. The defect is merely an irregularity. But in truth the difficulty is disposed of by sections 99 and 108, Civil Procedure Code.

arguments.court_reasoning: Applies to signing/authentication irregularities but not to lack of formal delivery

arguments.claim: section 537 CrPC cures irregularities in criminal judgments similar to CPC ss 99 and 108

anchor.surface_text: But in truth the difficulty is disposed of by sections 99 and 108, Civil Procedure Code. That was a civil case. This is a criminal one. But section 537 of the Criminal Procedure Code does much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 do on the civil. The principle underlying them is the same.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the companyrt at the moment of delivery so that he can, if necessary, stop delivery and say that he has changed his mind. There is numberneed for him

arguments.court_reasoning: Cures procedural irregularities but core of judgment is formal delivery which cannot be cured

arguments.claim: a judgment is the final decision intimated by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, a judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way.

arguments.claim: Judges retain right to change mind until formal delivery of judgment (locus poenitentiae)

anchor.surface_text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae, and indeed last minute alterations sometimes do occur. Therefore, however much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court.

arguments.claim: Public policy requires certainty; cannot investigate whether signed draft was final opinion of deceased judge

anchor.surface_text: We feel it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion or was only intended to be a tentative draft sent with an unwritten understanding that he is free to change his mind

arguments.claim: Signed drafts are not judgments until formally delivered; judges who die cannot participate in delivery

anchor.surface_text: Views similar to this were expressed by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court consisting of nine Judges in the year 1867 in Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee. ... Clearly, we are met today for the first and only time to give judgment in these appeals and it appears to me, beyond question, that Judges who have died or have retired from the court cannot join in the judgment which is to be delivered today

arguments.claim: The judgment purportedly delivered by Kidwai J on 5th January 1953 was not valid because Bhargava J died before delivery

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

arguments.claim: High Courts have power to make rules on judgment delivery under Article 225 Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The power is not conferred, or rather continued, under article 225 of the Constitution. The Allahabad High Court framed its present set of Rules in 1952.

arguments.claim: After signing, judgment cannot be altered except clerical errors (s369 CrPC)

anchor.surface_text: section 369 of the Criminal Procedure Code which provides that Save as otherwise provided by this Code or by any other law for the time being in force or, in the case of a High Court, by the Letters Patent or other instrument constituting such High Court, no court, when it has signed its judgment, shall alter or review the same except to correct a clerical error.

holdings.text: the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion is that the judgment which Kidwai J. purported to deliver on 5th January, 1953, was not a valid judgment because the other member of the Bench died before it could be delivered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formal delivery in open court by extant judges required; signed draft remains tentative until pronounced; deceased judge cannot participate; supported by precedent and public policy

holdings.text: a judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, a judgment within the meaning of these sections is the final decision of the court intimated to the parties and to the world at large by formal pronouncement or delivery in open court. It is a judicial act which must be performed in a judicial way.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judgment essence is formal intimation in open court; authentication irregularities curable but core delivery not; draws from CrPC ss 369,537 and purpose of rules for certainty

holdings.text: Judges have the right to change their mind up to the moment the judgment is delivered. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae

anchor.surface_text: Now up to the moment the judgment is delivered Judges have the right to change their mind. There is a sort of locus poenitentiae, and indeed last minute alterations sometimes do occur.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Draft remains alterable until formal delivery; signing does not crystallize; judge must be alive to exercise change of mind

holdings.text: we do not intend to construe these rules too technically because they are designed... to further the ends of justice... nor do we desire to curtail the jurisdiction which the Privy Council point out is inherent in courts to make good inherent defects caused by accidents such as death

anchor.surface_text: We do not intend to construe these rules too technically because they are designed, as indeed are all rules, to further the ends of justice and must not be viewed too narrowly nor do we desire to curtail the jurisdiction which the Privy Council point out is inherent in courts to make good inherent defects caused by accidents such as death.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pronounced and delivered not distinct requirements; rules for justice, not technicality; inherent power to cure accidental defects like death before signing

holdings.text: The court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect

anchor.surface_text: The court must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect. The case of a Judge who has gone on leave before signing the judgment may call for more comment, but even so the convenience of the court and the interest of litigants must prevail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accidents like death or leave before signing create curable irregularity; supported by Privy Council and CrPC s537 analogous to CPC ss99,108

holdings.text: it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion

anchor.surface_text: We feel it would be against public policy to leave the door open for an investigation whether a draft sent by a Judge was intended to embody his final and unalterable opinion or was only intended to be a tentative draft sent with an unwritten understanding that he is free to change his mind

holdings.reasoning_summary: Certainty requires no post-death inquiry into tentative drafts; signed drafts not final without delivery; public policy demands finality only upon pronouncement

holdings.text: however much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, however much a draft judgment may have been signed beforehand, it is nothing but a draft till formally delivered as the judgment of the court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Signing authenticates but delivery activates; pre-delivery acts non-judicial and alterable

precedents.citation: Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram 1 ; A.I.R. 1938 P.C. 292

anchor.surface_text: It is at page 295 of Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram 1 . The facts are number the same as here because the judgment was actually delivered in open companyrt and both the judges who companystituted the Bench were present and companycurred in it. But before it companyld be signed, one Judge went on leave. A.I.R. 1938 P.C. 292.

precedents.case_name: Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: Rules regarding signing and dating of judgments are directory and court has inherent jurisdiction to cure defects caused by judge's death or leave after pronouncement but before signing; such defects are irregularities curable under procedural sections
precedents.cited_holding: The rule does number say that if its requirements are number companyplied with the judgment shall be a nullity... A Judge may die after giving judgment but before he has had a reasonable opportunity to sign it. The companyrt must have inherent jurisdiction to supply such a defect.

precedents.citation: Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee 1 ; 9 W.R.I. F.B.

anchor.surface_text: Views similar to this were expressed by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court companysisting of nine Judges in the year 1867 in Mahomed Akil v. Asadunnissa Bibee 1 . In that case, three of the seven Judges who companystituted the Bench handed in signed judgments to the Registrar of the companyrt. Before the judgment companyld be delivered, two of them retired and one died. A Full Bench of nine Judges was companyvened to companysider whether the drafts of those three Judges companyld be accepted as judgments of the companyrt.

precedents.cited_proposition: Signed drafts of judgments handed in by judges who die or retire before delivery cannot be treated as formal judgments of the court; judgments must be delivered and pronounced in open court
precedents.cited_holding: judgments should be delivered and pronounced in open companyrt... Judges who have died or have retired from the companyrt cannot join in the judgment which is to be delivered today... The mere arguments and expressions of opinion of individual Judges... are number judgments. A judgment in the eye of the law is the final decision of the whole companyrt.
